title: Helen Mirren rules in turquoise gown with aquamarine maxi coat at Catherine The Great premiere in LA
text:
She starred as Elizabeth I in a HBO mini series in 2005.

And now, Helen Mirren is back on HBO as another major female ruler - Catherine The Great.

And on Thursday, the British actress headlined a special screening for series at LA's Hammer Museum.

In the spotlight: Helen Mirren, 74, was the star at a premiere in Los Angeles on Thursday night for her HBO mini series Catherine The Great

Mirren, 74, who won an Oscar for her portrayal of Elizabeth II in The Queen, plays the legendary Empress of Russia in the four-part series premiering on the premium subscription channel on October 21.

Naturally, she chose a regal ensemble for her night in the spotlight.

She opted for a full-length turquoise dress with aquamarine maxi coat that had voluminous long sleeves and fanned out around her as she posed for photos.

Mirren accessorized with a statement necklace and matching pendant earrings.

Her hair was in a bouffant style blown back from her forehead and she carried a small purple clutch.

Joining Mirren at the screening was her co-star Jason Clarke who plays military leader and statesman - and Catherine's longtime lover - Grigory Potemkin.

The Australian actor, 50, wore a gray two-piece suit with pale blue shirt and black tie.

Clarke and Mirren showed off their real-life chemistry as they posed up a storm together for the cameras.

Catherine The Great reigned from 1762 until her death at age 67 in 1796.

She came to power after orchestrating a coup against her husband Peter II, whom she forced to abdicate.

A few days after signing the instrument of abdication, Peter II was assassinated.

Under her leadership, Russia grew to be one of the great powers of Europe but as a female ruler, Catherine relied heavily on the men around her to lead her armies, implement her foreign policy and meet her carnal desires.

The mini series charts the latter years of the empress' 34-year reign and was filmed in Russia, Latvia and Lithuania.
